page.title: 15The Sibthorpe Dovecote
page.content: Sibthorpe is a small hamlet outside of Elston and the A46.The main attraction is the dovecote.It was built in 1370,after the Norman conquest and used by the monks in the nearby monastry for pigeon storage.In the dovecote are 1334 holes that the pigeons laid eggs in.The monks then came and collected and ate the eggs.The dovecote entrance is a small wooden door 11 cm thick.It was small so that no birds could escape while a monk was entering.The dovecote is 9.14 metres tall,it has 90 cm thick walls and its internal diameter is 7.80288 metres. It is made of Sleaford stone and held together by limestone mortar.The famine of 1360 encouraged the monks to build it.The original owner was William de Sibthorpe,now it is Michael Burton,a local farmer.
